key_points: Tiger Woods was involved in a car crash in Rolling Hills Estates earlier this year, which left him with a broken leg.
Los Angeles County sheriff's officials determined the crash was caused by Woods driving at nearly twice the speed limit and failing to handle a curve.
The crash occurred on a notorious stretch of Hawthorne Boulevard known for bad accidents.
Woods' vehicle hit a median, crossed into an opposing lane, hit a tree, and then rolled over.
Data from the vehicle's black box showed Woods was traveling 75 mph upon hitting the tree.
Woods did not hit the brakes before the collision, possibly hitting the accelerator inadvertently, and does not recall the crash.
Woods was trapped in the vehicle until rescued by firefighters and paramedics.
Sheriff Alex Villanueva stated Woods showed no signs of impairment and was not charged with a crime or cited for an infraction.
Woods was in Los Angeles County for a two-day video shoot and was driving a courtesy vehicle at the time of the crash.
Woods acknowledged the sheriff's investigation in a statement and thanked the responders, focusing on his recovery and family.
